FAST GAME EXPECTED
WITH RICHMOND AT
HOMEWOOD TOMORROW
Clayton Moved to Wing
As Strader Breaks •
Into Lineup
PASSES ARE JAY THREAT
Kicking Department Improved
During Week's Hard
Practice
(Lineup will be found on Page 4)

Johns Hopkins will meet the
University of Richmond at Homewood Field at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow. The Jay team which will
start the battle will be a slightly
revamped one in the line, from the
aggregation which put Haverford
to rout last week.
Richmond enters the fray as
slightly the underdog, but nevertheless is expected to work Van
Orman's team hard. Richmond
has had a season similar to Hopkins in that they defeated Duke
University 9 to 7 but lost to Navy
last Saturday when Hopkins won
from Haverford 12 to 0.
Veteran Team
The Virginians are putting an
organization on the field which '
contains several familiar faces
from last year's battle. Headed
by Capt. R. Sanford the list of
veterans include De Motte, Peterson, 'Primmer, Newcombe, and
Sebold as regulars. Dillon and
Nolan were subs last year but are
found to be starters tomorrow.
All told eight of the eleven men
taking the field are those who
have formerly opposed the Hopkins onslaughts. Richmond's loss
of Penzold, star quarter, and
Rickey, who was hurt in the early
part of the season, will be sorely felt
as they were the mainstays of last
year's team when they played at
Homewood. Aside from Penzold
the backfield will be the same as
last year's team.
As both Van Orman and Dobson use the same style of play,
light and speedy, the game should
prove fast and spectacular. A
comparison of weights of the two
teams shows them to be of equal
weight, although Richmond seems
to have the poundage more evenly
distributed. On the ends and at
center is where the weights are
noticeably different.
Clayton Still Shifting

The changing of Clayton from
center to end as a running mate
to Captain Mallonee and. starting
Strader at center should prove
worthy. Clayton, former backfield man, will be more at home at
the wing position while Strader,
the new snapper-back, has had
considerable experience as he was
former All Maryland center while
he was at Western Maryland. Biddison and Leibensperger at tackle
and Dill and Kaufman will complete the lirfe.
The backfield remains intact as
Lyons will call the signals, with
Pindell and Lawrence at half and
Boynton at fullback.
The forward passing combina(Continued on Page 3, Col. 1)

Harvard was defeated again Saturday when Holy Cross came from
behind in the second half, scoring
nineteen points to win by the score
of 19 to 14.
*

Printed by The Read-Taylor Press, South and Lombard Streets

WE COUNSEL MODERATION
The howls of delight that were elicited by the FreshmanSophomore run-in last Friday seem sufficient evidence that the
fray was stamped with the universal approval oi the upperclassmen. The NEWS-LETTER, however, holds no such unqualitied view.
There is, of course, much to be said in favor of the struggle.
It marked the beginning of that group-consciousness, known on
the campus as "class spirit," which after it has developed from
its present hazy and indistinct shape, will be the standard by
which the success or failure will ultimately be judged. Also,
the self respect of the harassed frosh must be materially increased
by the knowledge that they have at last registered a more than
passive disapproval of their lot by engaging in combat with their
tormenters.
This question of class fights, in common with any other problem, has two sides. Last Friday's battle, for instance, was pointless. It was organized by upperclassmen for their own amusement. In that respect it proved highly satisfactory; whether it
offered equal advantages to the participants is a debatable question. No freshman can truthfully say what he was fighting for
or why, neither could any sophomore; thus the battle dragged
on endlessly. The fact that one student was rather seriously
shaken up did not serve to help the situation.
As usual we counsel moderation. When the Pep Committee exceeds its powers and tries to exact more than compliance
with regulations, every freshman may fight as hard as he pleases
with the blessings of the NEWS-LETTER on his head. In other
cases, unless the individual has an inborn lust for bloodshed, we
tdvise him to avoid trouble.

WHY THE NEGLECT
The required two weeks have rolled around, but as yet
the most valuable of the regulations have not been enforced.
No move has been made toward giving out activities buttons
or enforcing the rule that every freshman must be out for at
least one activity.
It is time for the Pep Committee, which has been enthusiastically enforcing all the other regulations and doing a little
aimless paddling on the side, to really get to work and attend to
its most important task. Buttons should be distributed, and
enforcement begun, at once. Enough time has been waisted
• already.

Pourboire

SPORTS

Harvard's defense was woefully
weak against a forward passing
game, and it was largely by means
of the aerial game that Holy Cross
gained consistently.
The Crimson, however, was considerably weakened by the absence
of Captain Coady, star tackle, and
Stafford, varsity quarterback.
*

Dartmouth, after rolling up tremendous scores against Norwich
and Hobart in the first two games
of the season, found Virginia Poly
much stronger than was expected
and the Green team had quite a difficult time in beating the Virginians
21 to 0.

Gertrude Ederle undoubtedly did a noble thing for her sex
and, of course, for her country also, when she swam the English
Channel last summer, as did Mrs. Corson, who covered the Channel "for her two kiddies," although it is reported that the younger
one did not recognize her mother on Mrs. Carson's return to
New York.

*

*-

These feats brought about many changes,among the weaker
sex. Especially is this evident on the campus at Hopkins.

Once meek and retiring, the female student has suddenly,
but not without reason, become bold and daring. No longer does
she timidly enter the Barn, waiting until the noisy males have
purchased their lunch, then ask very gently, "Doctor, may I have
a Coca-Cola, please?" Now, the co-ed conies rushing and pushing into the Barn and as soon as one foot is firmly planted on
the floor inside calls out in a high but piercing voice, "Hey, Doc!
Gimme a coke!"

It has only been three months since Miss Ederle swam the
Channel, but so many great changes have been brought about
since then that we fear greatly that on some nice, sunny fall day
in the near future, picking up the "Y" News, we will discover
that it has been edited by a female.

We would like to make a request to Dr. Ames that he absolutely forbid any sophomore class from forcing any freshman to
swim across the pond in part of the Barn. We realize that this
would be very amusing if permitted, but also that eventually some
bright upperclassman would time one of the crossings and competition would immediately begin, finally resulting with some exceptional record being made. But here is on what we base our
request. With a plentiful amount of grease in the kitchen, the
Barn and sundry bathing suits with Gertrude Ederle's signature
attached on the campus, we feel quite certain that Miss Betty
would consider it her duty to duplicate Miss Ederle's accomplishment and would break all records, thus bringing more humil-

iation on the already weakening stronger sex.

BYRD PLANNING TROUBLE
FOR HOPKINS

ZERO APOLOGIZES IN
DORM DOINGS

(Continued "ram Page I, Column 2)

Hopkins. They lost to the stronger Chicago eleven 21 to 0 last Saturday but they are not at all
downhearted and they are working hard until after dark preparing for the Yale game. May they
have the best of luck in that game.
All this preparation and training
is getting them into good condition for the Hopkins game and the
Blue Jays will do well not to put
too much trust into the current
rumors that they are the favorites
and will not have a hard time with
Maryland. From the looks of
things down at College Park
Maryland means business.

literary committee is appointed

THERE'S no other sport on the calendar to
compare with smoking a jimmy-pipe packed
with P. A. Indoors and out. Any season. You
win even when you draw, if you get what we
mean. And how you will draw, once you know
the wonderful taste of Prince Albert!
Cool as an over-cut notice from the dean.
Sweet as the thoughts of a holiday. Fragrant as
woodland flowers after a spring shower. P. A.
never bites your tongue or parches your throat.
The Prince Albert process fixed that the day
P. A. matriculated.
Come out for this major sport. Get yourself
a tidy red tin at that nearby smoke-shop where
they hand out P. A. sunshine. You and Prince
Albert are going to be great buddies right from
the start. Because there just never was another
tobacco like Prince Albert!

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 15, 1926

I INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS

Wt.

• In almost every college paper we
see -Frosh Defeat Sophs," or some
such heading. The class of '30 at
Hopkins must have been reading
the newspapers and got inspiration
therefrom, for it certainly put up
a beautiful scrap last week. But,
then, perhaps they were trying "to
be different," and were goaded beyond the limits of human endurance. Who knows?

Hurray! One of the NEWS-LETTERS' -brain-children" takes effect
—but, unfortunately, at Haverford.
Starting October 4, the Juniors and
Seniors of that college shall have
unlimited cuts—with as many provisions as the United States makes
for entering the World Court. They
have unlimited cuts, but—"The
Dean is empowered to put on probation any student who takes an unreasonable amount of cuts," et cetera ad infinitum. Blah! we want
the whole loaf or no bread at all.
*
Dr. J. Rosslyn Eys of Antioch
College, after a statistical study of
the question, arrives at the following conclusion:
"The smoker smokes because it is
a social habit. He has low scholarship because he is sociable. Solitude of mind is incompatible with
the gregarious instinct." "Doc"
Adams may yet lose his tobacco
trade, if the highbrows come to
Hopkins.
*
The Daily Cardinal tells us many
truths already known, indeed, trite
to undergraduates. In an editorial
it cusses Prohibition all around. It
is old stuff to us, but news to the
older generation. Therefore, it is
made much of.

FAST GAME EXPECTED
WITH RICHMOND AT
HOMEWOOD TOMORROW
Clayton Moved to Wing
As Strader Breaks •
Into Lineup
PASSES ARE JAY THREAT
Kicking Department Improved
During Week's Hard
Practice
(Lineup will be found on Page 4)

Johns Hopkins will meet the
University of Richmond at Homewood Field at 2:30 P. M. tomorrow. The Jay team which will
start the battle will be a slightly
revamped one in the line, from the
aggregation which put Haverford
to rout last week.
Richmond enters the fray as
slightly the underdog, but nevertheless is expected to work Van
Orman's team hard. Richmond
has had a season similar to Hopkins in that they defeated Duke
University 9 to 7 but lost to Navy
last Saturday when Hopkins won
from Haverford 12 to 0.
Veteran Team
The Virginians are putting an
organization on the field which '
contains several familiar faces
from last year's battle. Headed
by Capt. R. Sanford the list of
veterans include De Motte, Peterson, 'Primmer, Newcombe, and
Sebold as regulars. Dillon and
Nolan were subs last year but are
found to be starters tomorrow.
All told eight of the eleven men
taking the field are those who
have formerly opposed the Hopkins onslaughts. Richmond's loss
of Penzold, star quarter, and
Rickey, who was hurt in the early
part of the season, will be sorely felt
as they were the mainstays of last
year's team when they played at
Homewood. Aside from Penzold
the backfield will be the same as
last year's team.
As both Van Orman and Dobson use the same style of play,
light and speedy, the game should
prove fast and spectacular. A
comparison of weights of the two
teams shows them to be of equal
weight, although Richmond seems
to have the poundage more evenly
distributed. On the ends and at
center is where the weights are
noticeably different.
Clayton Still Shifting

The changing of Clayton from
center to end as a running mate
to Captain Mallonee and. starting
Strader at center should prove
worthy. Clayton, former backfield man, will be more at home at
the wing position while Strader,
the new snapper-back, has had
considerable experience as he was
former All Maryland center while
he was at Western Maryland. Biddison and Leibensperger at tackle
and Dill and Kaufman will complete the lirfe.
The backfield remains intact as
Lyons will call the signals, with
Pindell and Lawrence at half and
Boynton at fullback.
The forward passing combina(Continued on Page 3, Col. 1)

Harvard was defeated again Saturday when Holy Cross came from
behind in the second half, scoring
nineteen points to win by the score
of 19 to 14.
*

Printed by The Read-Taylor Press, South and Lombard Streets

WE COUNSEL MODERATION
The howls of delight that were elicited by the FreshmanSophomore run-in last Friday seem sufficient evidence that the
fray was stamped with the universal approval oi the upperclassmen. The NEWS-LETTER, however, holds no such unqualitied view.
There is, of course, much to be said in favor of the struggle.
It marked the beginning of that group-consciousness, known on
the campus as "class spirit," which after it has developed from
its present hazy and indistinct shape, will be the standard by
which the success or failure will ultimately be judged. Also,
the self respect of the harassed frosh must be materially increased
by the knowledge that they have at last registered a more than
passive disapproval of their lot by engaging in combat with their
tormenters.
This question of class fights, in common with any other problem, has two sides. Last Friday's battle, for instance, was pointless. It was organized by upperclassmen for their own amusement. In that respect it proved highly satisfactory; whether it
offered equal advantages to the participants is a debatable question. No freshman can truthfully say what he was fighting for
or why, neither could any sophomore; thus the battle dragged
on endlessly. The fact that one student was rather seriously
shaken up did not serve to help the situation.
As usual we counsel moderation. When the Pep Committee exceeds its powers and tries to exact more than compliance
with regulations, every freshman may fight as hard as he pleases
with the blessings of the NEWS-LETTER on his head. In other
cases, unless the individual has an inborn lust for bloodshed, we
tdvise him to avoid trouble.

WHY THE NEGLECT
The required two weeks have rolled around, but as yet
the most valuable of the regulations have not been enforced.
No move has been made toward giving out activities buttons
or enforcing the rule that every freshman must be out for at
least one activity.
It is time for the Pep Committee, which has been enthusiastically enforcing all the other regulations and doing a little
aimless paddling on the side, to really get to work and attend to
its most important task. Buttons should be distributed, and
enforcement begun, at once. Enough time has been waisted
• already.

Pourboire

SPORTS

Harvard's defense was woefully
weak against a forward passing
game, and it was largely by means
of the aerial game that Holy Cross
gained consistently.
The Crimson, however, was considerably weakened by the absence
of Captain Coady, star tackle, and
Stafford, varsity quarterback.
*

Dartmouth, after rolling up tremendous scores against Norwich
and Hobart in the first two games
of the season, found Virginia Poly
much stronger than was expected
and the Green team had quite a difficult time in beating the Virginians
21 to 0.

Gertrude Ederle undoubtedly did a noble thing for her sex
and, of course, for her country also, when she swam the English
Channel last summer, as did Mrs. Corson, who covered the Channel "for her two kiddies," although it is reported that the younger
one did not recognize her mother on Mrs. Carson's return to
New York.

*

*-

These feats brought about many changes,among the weaker
sex. Especially is this evident on the campus at Hopkins.

Once meek and retiring, the female student has suddenly,
but not without reason, become bold and daring. No longer does
she timidly enter the Barn, waiting until the noisy males have
purchased their lunch, then ask very gently, "Doctor, may I have
a Coca-Cola, please?" Now, the co-ed conies rushing and pushing into the Barn and as soon as one foot is firmly planted on
the floor inside calls out in a high but piercing voice, "Hey, Doc!
Gimme a coke!"

It has only been three months since Miss Ederle swam the
Channel, but so many great changes have been brought about
since then that we fear greatly that on some nice, sunny fall day
in the near future, picking up the "Y" News, we will discover
that it has been edited by a female.

We would like to make a request to Dr. Ames that he absolutely forbid any sophomore class from forcing any freshman to
swim across the pond in part of the Barn. We realize that this
would be very amusing if permitted, but also that eventually some
bright upperclassman would time one of the crossings and competition would immediately begin, finally resulting with some exceptional record being made. But here is on what we base our
request. With a plentiful amount of grease in the kitchen, the
Barn and sundry bathing suits with Gertrude Ederle's signature
attached on the campus, we feel quite certain that Miss Betty
would consider it her duty to duplicate Miss Ederle's accomplishment and would break all records, thus bringing more humil-

iation on the already weakening stronger sex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 15, 1926
BYRD PLANNING TROUBLE
FOR HOPKINS

Hopkins. They lost to the stronger Chicago eleven 21 to 0 last Saturday but they are not at all
downhearted and they are working hard until after dark preparing for the Yale game. May they
have the best of luck in that game.
All this preparation and training
is getting them into good condition for the Hopkins game and the
Blue Jays will do well not to put
too much trust into the current
rumors that they are the favorites
and will not have a hard time with
Maryland. From the looks of
things down at College Park
Maryland means business.

literary committee is appointed

• In almost every college paper we
see -Frosh Defeat Sophs," or some
such heading. The class of '30 at
Hopkins must have been reading
the newspapers and got inspiration
therefrom, for it certainly put up
a beautiful scrap last week. But,
then, perhaps they were trying "to
be different," and were goaded beyond the limits of human endurance. Who knows?

Hurray! One of the NEWS-LETTERS' -brain-children" takes effect
—but, unfortunately, at Haverford.
Starting October 4, the Juniors and
Seniors of that college shall have
unlimited cuts—with as many provisions as the United States makes
for entering the World Court. They
have unlimited cuts, but—"The
Dean is empowered to put on probation any student who takes an unreasonable amount of cuts," et cetera ad infinitum. Blah! we want
the whole loaf or no bread at all.
*
Dr. J. Rosslyn Eys of Antioch
College, after a statistical study of
the question, arrives at the following conclusion:
"The smoker smokes because it is
a social habit. He has low scholarship because he is sociable. Solitude of mind is incompatible with
the gregarious instinct." "Doc"
Adams may yet lose his tobacco
trade, if the highbrows come to
Hopkins.
*
The Daily Cardinal tells us many
truths already known, indeed, trite
to undergraduates. In an editorial
it cusses Prohibition all around. It
is old stuff to us, but news to the
older generation. Therefore, it is
made much of.
